did.unittitle: Emma Weigley collection on Sarah Tyson Rorer

bioghist.p: Sarah Tyson Rorer (1849-1937) was a pioneer of dietetics and the most famous cooking teacher of her time. In 1882, she founded the Philadelphia Cooking School, where she offered cooking classes, a chemistry class, and classes on preparing proper meals for both the sick and healthy. She wrote popular magazine columns for Ladies Home Journal and for Table Talk, a Philadelphia-based monthly. She published her first cookbook, Mrs. Rorer's Philadelphia Cook Book, in 1886. Rorer closed her cooking school in 1903, and published her last cookbook in 1917. Later in her life, she became interested in politics, serving as president of the Lebanon County League of Democratic Women, and touring Pennsylvania at the age of 79 in support of Presidential candidate Al Smith. During the Great Depression of the 1930s, she lost her investments and her book royalties, and was destitute. She had to rely on the good will and generosity of former students and professional groups, who organized a pension fund for her.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials on Sarah Tyson Rorer collected by Emma Weigley for her 1971 New York University doctoral dissertation. Materials include: incoming and outgoing correspondence between Weigley and various libraries, associations, and individuals related to her research on Rorer; research notecards; correspondence and other materials related to the pension fund for Mrs. Rorer (1933-1937); and cookbooks, recipe pamphlets, and copies of Household News and Table Talk. The collection also includes a small batch of genealogical records on the Heston and Rorer families.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Schlesinger Library, Harvard University: Sarah Tyson Heston Rorer papers.
